children.name: look
children.definition: to turn your eyes towards sth so that you can see it:
examples: Look, there are some swans on the river.
look[C noun] [B1] when you turn your eyes to look at someone or something:
Sarah needed only one look at her daughter’s face to know something was wrong.
I was getting disapproving looks from the people around me.

children.name: look at
examples: ‘Come on, it’s time to go,’ he said, looking at his watch.
Look at me when I’m talking to you.

children.name: look into/out of/through/down etc
examples: Tom looked out the window over the dry, barren landscape.
I always look through the peephole before I open the door for anyone.
The teacher stopped and looked around to see if there were any questions.

children.name: look at sb/sth in amazement/ disbelief/ surprise etcin a way that shows you are surprised or shocked
examples: ‘You were a hippie?’ she asked, looking at her father in disbelief.

children.name: take a look
children.definition: take/ have a look  to look at sth, especially sth interesting or unusual:
examples: ‘I think there’s something wrong with the car.’ ‘Do you want me to have a look?’
take/ have a look at
We climbed to the top of the tower to have a look at the view.
‘You’d better take a look at this,’ she said, passing me a letter.
take/ have a good looklookvery carefully
Take a good look at the pictures and tell me if anyone looks familiar.
take/have a close looklookat sth very closely
He moved to the front of the crowd to have a closer look at the animal.

children.name: glance
children.definition: to lookquicklyat sb or sth and then look away again: liếc nhìn
examples: glance at
Dr Morse kept glancing nervously at his watch.
‘Some of you may not be happy about what I have to say,’ he began, glancing at Janey.
glance into/down/through etc
Glancing into Neil’s room, she noticed that his suitcase was packed.
glance[C noun] [B1]
glance at
A quick glance at the map showed that we were on the right road.
a backward glancea quick look back at the place you have left
I walked away without a wave or a backward glance.
a sidelong glancea quick look to one side
Tammy gave her sister a sidelong glance and the two started to giggle.

children.name: take a quick look
children.definition: take/ have a quick look to look at sth quickly in order tocheckthat everything is satisfactory: nhìn nhanh, kiểm tra nhanh

children.name: take/ have a quick look at/around/through etc
examples: He took a quick look in the mirror, and went out of the house.
She had a quick look around the room before letting the guests in.

children.name: take a peek
children.definition: take/have a peek to look at sth quickly and secretly, especially from a place where you cannot be seen: nhìn trộm, nhìn lén
examples: When I heard the noise in the next room, I couldn’t resist having a peek.

children.name: take/have a peek at
examples: If I'm passing by I might take a peek at the new premises.

children.name: take/have a peek in/into/through/over etc
examples: She opened the door and took a quick peek inside.

children.name: peek
children.definition: to look at sth quickly and secretly, especially from a place where you cannot be seen: nhìn trộm, nhìn lén.
examples: Close your eyes. Don't peek. I've got a surprise for you.

children.name: peek at
examples: The little girl peeked at me from behind her grandmother’s skirt.

children.name: peek in/into/through/over etc
examples: We tip-toed into the room and peeked in the crib without waking the baby.

children.name: peep
children.definition: to look at sthquicklyandsecretly, especially from a place where you cannot be seen: nhìn trộm

children.name: peep through/ into/ round
examples: Bobby peeped around the corner to see if anyone was coming.
We peeped through a crack in the fence and saw Mrs Finley talking to a strange-looking man.
I saw her peepingthroughthe curtains/intothe room.

children.name: take one look
children.definition: to look quickly at sb or sth that you have not seen before, and immediately decide what your opinion of them is:
examples: They opened the door to the room, took one look, and decided to go to another hotel.

children.name: take one look at
examples: She took one look at me and said she would not work with me.
The teacher took one look at his homework and told him he would have to redo it.

children.name: to stop looking at sb or sth
look away
children.definition: to turn your eyes away from sth that you were looking at: nhìn đi chỗ khác
examples: The accident scene was so horrible that I had to look away.
The minute he looked away, I crumpled the piece of paper and shoved it in my coat pocket.
look away from
She looked away from him, unable to tell him the truth

children.name: look up
children.definition: to stop looking at sth and turn your faceupwards, in order to see sb or talk to them: nhìn lên
examples: There was a loud bang outside the classroom, and we all looked up.

children.name: look up from
examples: ‘Goodbye, then,’ she said, without even looking up from her book.

children.name: look around
children.definition: /lookround  to turn your eyes away from what you were looking at and start to look at what is around you:

children.name: Alan put down his newspaper and looked around, ‘What was that noise?’
examples: The speaker finished her speech and looked round to see if there were any questions.

children.name: turn your face away
children.definition: to stop looking at sb or sth by turning your face in another direction, especially because you are embarrassed or upset: quay mặt đi
examples: He burped loudly, and she turned her face away in disgust.

children.name: turn your face away from
examples: Turning his face away from her, Glen began to cry.

children.name: avert your eyes/gaze
children.definition: avert your eyes/ gaze formal to deliberately turn your eyes away from what you are looking at, because you do not want to look at it any longer:
examples: The two averted their eyes as they passed each other in the hall.
When Celia dropped her robe, Richard averted his gaze and stepped back awkwardly.

children.name: to look for a long time
stare
children.definition: to look directly at sb or sth for a long time, without moving your eyes: nhìn chằm chằm
examples: It’s not polite to stare, you know.
stare[C noun] a long direct look:
Charles didn’t reply. He just gave his daughter an icy stare.
a blank/ vacant starea long look that does not show any thought or emotion
The suspect was described as having a blank stare after the shooting spree.

children.name: stare at
examples: Why are you staring at me like that?
She stared at the page for several minutes, trying to understand.
Ron kept silent and stared down at his food.

children.name: stare into/out of etc
examples: When he’s depressed, he just sits there, staring off into space.

children.name: stare back (at sb)stare at sb who is staring at you
examples: Everyone turned to look at him, and he stared stonily back.

children.name: stare (at sb/sth) in amazement/ horror/ disbelief etcin a way that shows you are surprised or shocked
examples: Donna stared in horror as the man fell to the floor.

children.name: stare sb downstare at sb until they stop staring at you
examples: Fenton stood tall and stared down the gunmen.

children.name: gaze
children.definition: to look at sth or sb for a long time, especially with a feeling of love or great pleasure - used especially in stories and literature: nhìn chằm chằm
examples: gaze[CS noun] [C2] turn your gaze
Toni turned her gaze back to the fireplace.

children.name: gaze at
examples: I lay back on the sand and gazed at the stars above.
Ruth gazed down at the sleeping child.

children.name: gaze out/into/through etc
examples: He stopped talking suddenly and gazed into the distance.
She sat gazing out the windows at the people walking by.

children.name: gape
children.definition: to look at sb or sth for a long time, especially with your mouth open, because you are very surprised or shocked: há hốc miệng nhìn
examples: People stopped to gape as she walked down the street in a see-through mini-dress.

children.name: gape at
examples: She stood there gaping at me, too shocked to speak.

children.name: gape in amazement/horror etc
examples: I could only gape in astonishment as I saw the man take the bottle from the shelf and put it under his coat.

children.name: gawk
children.definition: /gawp  informal to look at sb in a rude or annoying way, for example because they look unusual or are doing sth unusual: trố mắt nhìn
examples: Tourists walked around gawking at the people in traditional costumes.
I wanted to kill the morons who had gathered around me, gawping and pointing.

children.name: eye
children.definition: to look at sb or sth with interest or because you do not trust them: để mắt, dõi mắt
examples: Mavis eyed the old sewing machine. ‘Does this still work?’ she asked.
The two teams eyed each other warily, waiting for the game to begin.

children.name: look sb up and down
children.definition: to look very carefully at sb’s body and the clothes they are wearing, especially because you donotknowthem and you are trying to form anopinionof them:
examples: The hotel manager slowly looked the old man up and down and then asked him to leave.
‘Don’t be silly - you don’t need to lose weight,’ he said, looking her up and down.

children.name: glare
children.definition: to look angrily at sb: nhìn chừng chừng, nhìn giận giữ
examples: He sat there in silence, glaring angrily.
glare[C noun] [C2]
He looked me straight in the eye with a stern glare.

children.name: glare at
examples: ‘You can go if you want, but I’m staying,’ Denise said glaring at him.

children.name: glare toward/ across/ around etc
examples: Claude put down his fork and glared across the table.

children.name: look daggers at
children.definition: to look at sb very angrily, as if you would like to hurt them: nhìn trừng trừng, hầm hầm
examples: When I asked him what he’d done with the money he just looked daggers at me and refused to speak.
Julie must have heard you talking about her, because she was looking daggers at you from the next table.

children.name: give sb a dirty/black/filthy look
children.definition: to quickly look at sb angrily to show that you are angry with them, especially in a situation when you cannot tell them that you are angry: lườm
examples: I don’t know what I did to upset her, but she gave me a really filthy look when I walked into the meeting.
My aunt’s friends always used to give me dirty looks when I brought my kids over, because they knew I wasn’t married.

children.name: scowl
children.definition: to look at sb in an angry way, or make an angry, unhappy expression with your face: quắc mắt nhìn với vẻ cau có, giận dữ, cáu kỉnh
examples: Jane scowled and told them to get out.
‘What do you want?’ said the old man, scowling.
scowl[C noun]
A teenage girl was sitting alone in a corner with a scowl on her face.

children.name: scowl at
examples: What are you scowling at me for? You asked me to wake you up.

children.name: frown at
children.definition: to bring your eyebrows together and look at sb or sth with an annoyed, confused, or disapproving expression on your face: cau mày
examples: The teacher frowned at him and asked him to sit down.
When I got back to the table, Carolyn was frowning at the check.
‘Sibling rivalry?’ she asked, frowning at his use of psychological terms.
frown[C noun] [C2]
give sb a frown
He walked past her, giving her a judgmental frown.

children.name: if looks could kill
children.definition: use this when you are telling sb how another person looked at you in a very angry way, and you found this funny or frightening:
examples: You should’ve seen her face when she realized what I’d done - if looks could kill!

children.name: to look hard and with difficulty
squint
children.definition: to look hard at sth that you find difficult to see, and make your eyes narrower to try and see better: nheo mắt nhìn
examples: Bring your glasses or you’ll have to squint through the whole movie.

children.name: squint at
examples: She squinted at the sign but couldn’t read what it said.

children.name: squint through/ over/ into etc
examples: Driving down the narrow country road, Blackthorne squinted into the darkness.

children.name: peer
children.definition: to look with difficulty at sb or sth, especially because you cannot see very well or there is not enough light: nhòm, ngó

children.name: peer through/ into/ out etc
examples: Roger peered into the dark corridor to see what was making the noise.

children.name: peer at
examples: She adjusted her glasses and peered at the man.

children.name: screw up your eyes
children.definition: to try to make it easier to see sth by almost closing your eyes, especially because the light is too bright or because what you are looking at is very small: nheo mắt nhìn
examples: You have to screw up your eyes to see the figure in the bottom left of the picture.

children.name: view
children.definition: to look at something, especially because it is beautiful or you are interested in it
examples: view sth from sth
The mountain is best viewed from the north side.
Thousands of tourists come to view the gardens every year.
view a house/an apartment/a property(= go to see a house etc that you are interested in buying )
A few journalists were allowed to view the art exhibition the day before it opened.
I’d like to make an appointment to view the house on Clement Street that’s for sale.
view a photo
Click on the link toviewmore photos

children.name: admire
children.definition: to look at sth and think how beautiful or impressive it is: thưởng thức
examples: I was just admiring your lovely garden.
We stopped at the top of the mountain to admire the view.

children.name: eye contact
children.definition: when two people look at each other's eyes at the same time
examples: He's very shy and nevermakeseye contact.
If you're telling the truth, why are youavoidingeye contactwithme?
People who are lying tend to avoid eye contact.

children.name: In a formal interview, try to maintain good eye contact with the interviewers
